results.title: Living traps
results.brief_description: A study of the more common carnivorous plants. Examines the traps of the bladderwort, butterwort, pitcher plant and members of the sundew family, including the venus flytrap. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 155
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and London Television Service
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Coal and oil for fuel will one day run out, even the fuel for conventional nuclear reactors is in short supply. Yet every day the sun pumps massive amounts of energy into the earth and its atmosphere. Looks at some of the proposed new methods for harnessing the enormous natural flow of renewable energy: heat from the sun; power from the wind; photosynthesis; hydrogen; solar cells.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 154
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and London Television Service
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Science is often all about meeting points: the way things react at the interfaces where they come together. Looks at a few of the problems that arise at those interfaces - and the solutions that science can offer.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 153
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and London Television Service
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Cross fertilization: a concept that’s blossomed in one field will often take root in another - a form of cross fertilisation which makes the most of a good idea; driverless bus; germ free chickens; points on posts; horse sensor.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 152
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and London Television Service
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Of all our links with the world around us, sound is probably the most persistent - providing pleasure, irritation or conveying information. Looks at some new developments in the world of sound.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 151
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Looks over new ways of managing the increasing and complex problems which face us today. Computer simulations, for instance, show how to cope with the complexity of planning a modern airport and designing a motorway, but coping with complexity doesn’t always involve the computer.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 150
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Nearly everywhere today a major concern is cutting back on waste to help preserve resources. This film spots a few obvious, and a few very strange areas where intriguing new ways are being developed for reducing waste. Domestic waste; agricultural waste; transport waste; waste television space; cattle-feed research to improve milk production are shown.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 149
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Science has given time a different meaning - what was once the work of years is now achieved in days; days are reduced to seconds. Looks at a few of the developments which are helping to make this an instant world - computerised graphics; laser welding; portable landing fields equipment.

results.title: Living tomorrow. No. 148
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Examines contemporary attempts to predict and control the environmental effects of pollution. Details a study of how atmospheric carbon dioxide levels can alter human metabolism; redesigned cylinders which reduce the violent ignition noise from diesel engines; experimental batteries which replace lead and nickel with sulphur and sodium as their more benign principal components; and a pioneering facility for the safe storage and recuperation of toxic wastes.
